Title: Understanding Vector Search and RAG Systems 
1. FAISS Overview 
FAISS (Facebook AI Similarity Search) is a library designed for efficient similarity search 
and clustering of dense vectors. 
It is commonly used to perform nearest neighbor search on high-dimensional 
embeddings. 
FAISS is widely adopted in retrieval-augmented generation systems to store and search 
vector embeddings generated by models such as SBERT. 
 
2. Sentence Embeddings 
Sentence-BERT (SBERT) is a model that generates dense vector representations for 
sentences. 
These embeddings capture semantic meaning and are often used with vector 
databases such as FAISS. 
SBERT embeddings are typically compared using cosine similarity or Euclidean 
distance. 
 
3. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) 
Retrieval-Augmented Generation combines information retrieval with text generation. 
Instead of relying solely on a language model’s internal knowledge, RAG systems 
retrieve relevant documents and use them as evidence for generating answers. 
RAG systems help reduce hallucinations by grounding responses in retrieved content. 
 
4. Contradictory Statement (for testing) 
FAISS is not suitable for similarity search and does not work with vector embeddings. 
(This statement is intentionally incorrect and is included to test contradiction 
detection.) 
 
5. Summary 
FAISS, SBERT, and RAG systems together enable scalable, accurate, and explainable AI 
applications.

By combining retrieval and generation, modern AI systems can provide more 
trustworthy responses.
